title: Headings
description: Headings provide structure and natural segmentation to your content and are an important semantic device for understanding the structure of a page.

title: Text
description: In virtually every interface, displaying information via text is the core feature–and doing this semantically can require many different elements.

title: Links and buttons
description: Link and button tags are used to perform actions by interface actors. However, they are semantically different and should be chosen based on separate requirements.

title: Sizing type
description: There are many different units that can be used to size and constrain type–from static pixels to typographic units based on characters in the typeface.

title: Tracking and leading
description: Also known as letter spacing and line height—tracking and leading values are the kinds of details that (when applied correctly) take interface typography to the next level.

title: Text overflow
description: Real content almost always breaks typographic layouts in static designs. Setting guards using text overflow properties helps keep things looking consistent.

title: Custom typefaces
description: It’s common for interfaces to use custom typefaces for branding and conveying a certain mood but they come at a cost. Avoid long load times and text shifting with these strategies.

title: Internationalization
description: True internationalization requires different content provided in different languages, but there are some easy to follow rules to ensure interfaces look their best everywhere.
